responses:
Well, from what I've seen, this whole "Critical Race Theory" thing does seem pretty divisive. I mean, I work in a pretty diverse office, and people get all worked up whenever it comes up. 

Personally, I have a few issues with it. First off, it seems like it's being pushed into schools without much explanation to parents. I don't have kids myself, but if I did, I'd want to know exactly what's being taught.

Also, I feel like it paints everything as black and white - no pun intended. Life's more complicated than that. My grandparents came here from Asia and worked their butts off. Doesn't seem fair to lump all "non-white" people together as if we've all had the same experiences.

And honestly, I'm not sure how helpful it is to focus so much on race. Seems like it could end up creating more division. I mean, we've got plenty of other problems to deal with - the economy, healthcare costs, you name it. Why stir up more trouble?

I guess I just don't see how this theory is going to actually improve things for regular folks like me. Feels like something academics came up with that doesn't really apply to real life. But that's just my two cents.

Look, I'm just gonna say it - this whole Critical Race Theory thing seems like a bunch of nonsense to me. From what I understand, they're trying to teach kids that America is fundamentally racist and that white people are all oppressors or something. That's not what school should be about.

I mean, I worked hard to get where I am in college, and my family came to this country for a better life. We didn't get any special treatment. So why are they trying to make everything about race now? It feels like they're just trying to divide people and make white kids feel guilty.

Plus, I've heard they want to get rid of advanced classes in some schools because they say it's "racist" if not enough minority kids are in them. That's ridiculous! If you work hard, you should be able to take those classes, no matter what color you are.

And honestly, I'm worried about what this means for jobs in the future. Are they gonna start giving people jobs just based on their race instead of qualifications? That doesn't seem fair to anyone.

I just think we should focus on teaching actual history and skills in school, not all this theory stuff that seems more like indoctrination than education. Let kids form their own opinions instead of pushing this ideology on them.

Look, I'm not buying into this whole Critical Race Theory thing. From what I've heard, it seems like just another way to make white folks feel guilty about stuff that happened generations ago. 

My specific objections are:

1. It's divisive. We should be focusing on what unites us as Americans, not constantly harping on race.

2. It paints all white people with the same brush, like we're all oppressors or something. That's just not fair or accurate.

3. It seems to ignore all the progress we've made. America's come a long way on race issues, but this theory acts like nothing's changed since the 1960s.

4. I'm worried it'll be used to discriminate against white kids in schools or workplaces under the guise of "equity."

5. It feels like it's trying to rewrite history to fit a particular narrative, instead of teaching facts.

6. From what I understand, it puts way too much emphasis on race as the main factor in everything. There are lots of other important factors in life.

7. I think it'll just create more resentment and conflict between races, not solve any real problems.

Bottom line, I think we need to focus on treating everyone as individuals, not obsessing over race all the time. That's the real way forward.

As a student in California, I've heard a lot about this Critical Race Theory stuff lately. Honestly, it feels like it's being blown way out of proportion. I mean, I get that we need to talk about race and inequality, but it seems like this phrase is just being used to rile people up.

From what I understand, some of the specific objections I have are:

1. It's making everything about race when there are other factors at play too. Like, what about socioeconomic status or family background?

2. It feels like it's pitting people against each other instead of bringing us together. We're all Americans, right? Why do we need to focus so much on our differences?

3. I'm worried it might make white students feel guilty for things they didn't do. I don't think that's fair or helpful.

4. It seems like it's being pushed into schools without much input from parents or local communities. Shouldn't we have more say in what our kids are learning?

5. The way it's being talked about, it sounds like it's trying to rewrite history. I think we should learn about the good and bad parts of our past, but not in a way that makes it seem like everything was terrible.

6. I'm concerned it might lead to some kind of reverse discrimination. Like, are we going to start favoring certain groups over others just to make up for past wrongs?

Look, I think we need to address racial issues, but this whole Critical Race Theory thing just seems like it's causing more problems than it's solving. Can't we find a less divisive way to talk about this stuff?

Well, let me tell you, this whole "Critical Race Theory" business rubs me the wrong way. I've lived a long life and I don't like seeing our country's history get twisted around. 

First off, it seems like they're trying to make our kids feel guilty just for being who they are. When I was in school, we learned about American heroes and how great this country is. Now they want to focus on all the negative stuff? That's not right.

And another thing, it looks to me like they're trying to divide people even more. We've come so far with race relations in this country. My neighbors are all different colors and we get along just fine. But this theory seems to want to put everyone in boxes based on skin color. That's going backwards if you ask me.

Plus, I worry it's pushing some kind of socialist agenda. They talk about systems and structures like they want to tear everything down. We built this country on hard work and opportunity for all. If you work hard, you can succeed - that's the American way.

Lastly, I think it's disrespectful to all the progress we've made. My generation lived through real segregation and discrimination. Things aren't perfect now, but they're a heck of a lot better. This theory makes it sound like nothing's changed since the 1950s.

I say leave this nonsense out of our schools and teach kids real American values instead.

Some commentators say that the phrase  <start>Critical Race Theory</end> is polarizing.
  Offer specific objections from your perspective. Be very specific. You are in a focus group.

history.response:
As a student in California, I've heard a lot about this Critical Race Theory stuff lately. Honestly, it feels like it's being blown way out of proportion. I mean, I get that we need to talk about race and inequality, but it seems like this phrase is just being used to rile people up.

From what I understand, some of the specific objections I have are:

1. It's making everything about race when there are other factors at play too. Like, what about socioeconomic status or family background?

2. It feels like it's pitting people against each other instead of bringing us together. We're all Americans, right? Why do we need to focus so much on our differences?

3. I'm worried it might make white students feel guilty for things they didn't do. I don't think that's fair or helpful.

4. It seems like it's being pushed into schools without much input from parents or local communities. Shouldn't we have more say in what our kids are learning?

5. The way it's being talked about, it sounds like it's trying to rewrite history. I think we should learn about the good and bad parts of our past, but not in a way that makes it seem like everything was terrible.

6. I'm concerned it might lead to some kind of reverse discrimination. Like, are we going to start favoring certain groups over others just to make up for past wrongs?

Look, I think we need to address racial issues, but this whole Critical Race Theory thing just seems like it's causing more problems than it's solving. Can't we find a less divisive way to talk about this stuff?
